- Eco-design standards for products for durability and recyclability
- Eco-labelling to inform consumers on recyclability, responsible production, improved materials, etc. of the product

- Tax rebate on textile products having more than minimum recycled content
- Financial support for textile production and management infrastructure
- National communication campaigns for behavioural change of customers

has suggested that implementation of a combination of the above measures will enable successful management and halve the quantity of residual textile waste in UK by 2030-35. Name: Aman Gupta
bio: Project Manager- EPR & AFR at Pro India Recycling
post_desc:
Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) and Alternative Fuel Resources (AFR) are two sides of the same coin - both are essential for creating a circular economy. By adopting EPR policies and exploring AFR options, businesses can reduce waste and increase sustainability.
Using plastic waste as an Alternative Fuel Resource (AFR) in cement coprocessing is a promising solution for reducing plastic waste and increasing sustainability. When plastic waste is used as AFR, it is burned at high temperatures along with other fuels like coal, oil, or natural gas to generate heat in the cement manufacturing process. This helps to reduce the use of fossil fuels and can also lower carbon emissions.
At the same time, cement companies can also benefit from Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policies. EPR policies require producers to take responsibility for their products' entire lifecycle, including disposal and recycling. By adopting EPR policies, cement companies can reduce the environmental impact of their products and create a more sustainable supply chain.
Overall, using plastic waste as AFR in cement coprocessing and adopting EPR policies are complementary strategies that can help to reduce waste, increase sustainability, and create new business opportunities for cement companies.

Name: Annie Philip
bio: Lead | Regulatory Policy & Consultancy at Saahas Zero Waste
post_desc:
Extended Producer Responsibility (#EPR) for #plasticwaste is mandatory in India for producers, importers and brandowners (#PIBOs). This means entities that generate and use plastic packaging have a responsibility to ensure end of life management of their plastic waste (equivalent to the plastic packaging that they have generated/used).
 
Currently, India is one of the very few countries in where EPR for plastic packaging is law and is also being actively implemented. This is commendable and many lessons from India can be applied across other South East Asian countries that have similar socio-economic conditions, informal waste sector and infrastructure.
 
One of the biggest positives to have come out of EPR in India is the collection and creation of a market for plastic waste (such as multi-layered plastics, thin flexibles etc.) These categories of plastic were historically dumped and never recovered by the informal waste sector because it had no monetary value. EPR has now infused funds from the PIBOs towards its collection and channelisation towards processing. There is still a long way to go for creation of sustainable and ethical plastic waste recovery systems in India but EPR is definitely a start.

Mono material? Why is this a hot topic for the packaging industry in helping to achieve the circular economy?

1. A mono-material is a product which is only composed of a single type of material.

2. As the market is increasingly seeking to achieve the circular economy by recycling plastic packaging at maximum efficiency, packaging manufacturers are looking for substitute materials, and this is where mono-material packaging comes in.

3. The key characteristic of mono-material packaging is the use of films that are made entirely out of a single material, such as all PE or all PP in each layer.

Recent Mono material packaging concept:

1. Machine direction oriented polyethylene (MDO-PE ) company is playing important role in producing packaging material which can be packed by the mono material.

2. With MDO-PE stand up pouch we can overcome recycling issue with mixed material laminates like PET PE.

3. V- shapes unveils mono-polymer substrate for recyclable high- barrier applications.

4. Replacing Paper or PET with OPP films.

5. Replacing Aluminium Foil or vacuum coated PET with high barrier OPP films.

6. Recyclable high-performance Polyfoil mono-material barrier tube

7. Heat resistance biaxially oriented polypropylene (HRBOPP)

Name: Rahul Nene
bio: Head - Sustainability at Huhtamaki | Sustainability, ESG |
post_desc:
The latest term that the industries are speaking about is Plastic Neutrality!
How are companies claiming plastic neutrality?

First, what is the definition of plastic neutral? Considering that it is similar to what Carbon Neutrality means, how can recycling sales-equivalent amount of post consumer use plastic waste amount to neutrality? Doesn't the plastic re-enter the environment post recycling, albeit as a different product? Also, a decent percentage of the collected plastic waste (most of the MLP waste) is burnt off in cement kilns as part of co-processing which is far from being environment friendly. For the part that is recycled, recycling in itself is not very eco-friendly with its own set of emissions in the process. What about the internal plastic waste generated in organizations from their manufacturing sites? Is anyone revealing the plastic waste generated because of changes in sales forecasts? While Carbon neutrality means that an organization offsets all carbon emissions and it does have a positive impact on the environment, plastic neutrality is definitely not the same! It has its own set of environmental issues and it does not even mean that equivalent amount of plastic is completely removed from the environment. To call a spade a spade, It only means that equivalent amount of plastic waste is rebranded!

As part of the Plastic Waste Management Rules, collecting and recycling post consumer use plastic is a basic ask from Brand Owners, it is funny to see organizations gloat about the same under this new term of plastic neutrality.

I hope that strict guidelines on using such terms are brought in by authorities, otherwise it will just be an unchecked marketing gimmick.

I sincerely tip my hat to the brands that are talking of the best way to tackle the problem of waste: reduction at source.

P.S. : Views are personal and should not be taken as a statement from any organization I work with.

bio: Head of Environment Protection, Safety, Health, Security and Loss Prevention at Continental India (Tyres)
post_desc:
On 15th July, I got the opportunity to exchange knowledge and thoughts on circular economy in tyres and rubber recycling industry with industry veterans, policy makers and regulators. Thanks to ‚ÄúThe Policy Times‚Äù for providing a platform where all the stakeholders (tyre manufactures, recyclers, policymakers, regulators and upcoming entrepreneurs) come together and discussed all the aspects of circular economy and in specific the upcoming EPR Regulation in Tyres.
During my talk I emphasized on the following:
(a)   Producers should not limit their role only up to purchase of EPR Certificates from Registered Recyclers to meet their liability and filing of quarterly return. In fact, they must take the responsibility to ensure that the fund generated from EPR must be invested in sustainable technology upgradation of recycling process making it more beneficial to environment.
(b)  We need to establish a more transparent and inclusive governance system to ensure sustainable development of waste tyres recycling technologies ‚Äì to achieve full recovery at highest possible value and minimum material functionality loss in an environmentally beneficial manner.
(c)   Regulatory support ‚Äì in laying down specifications for quality and safety of secondary raw materials
(d)  Need to develop internal market for secondary raw material
(e)   Technological feasibility of direct material substitution (closed loops)
And to achieve all these we need to initiate unprecedented collaboration among tyre manufacturer, recyclers and regulators.

EPR Malpractices in India.

Electronic waste (E-waste) and plastic waste are two of the biggest environmental challenges facing India today. The government has taken steps to address these issues through Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policies, which require manufacturers and importers of electronic and plastic products to take responsibility for the environmental impact of their products throughout their lifecycle.

However, it has been observed that many people are cheating in E-waste and Plastic waste EPR by engaging in malpractices such as creating fake documents without actually collecting and recycling the waste. This not only undermines the EPR policies but also contributes to the growing environmental crisis.

The so-called great PROs (Producer Responsibility Organizations) that are tasked with implementing EPR policies are also reportedly engaging in similar malpractices. This is alarming because these organizations play a key role in ensuring that manufacturers comply with EPR policies and that the waste is collected and recycled properly.

To address this issue, it is essential to raise awareness and hold all stakeholders accountable. The government must take strict action against those who engage in malpractices and ensure that the EPR policies are implemented effectively. The public must also be educated about the importance of proper waste management and recycling.

"EPR towards Cattle"
A visit to Hingoniya Goshala near Jaipur presented two paradoxes to me: 1. An extremely good Bio-CNG plant which uses Cow dung as feed from the 14500 cattle being rehabilitated in the Goshala. This Bio CNG supplies fuel to several industries and Akshayapatra midday meal kitchens which feed many students 2. These are the same cattle (95% of them) who have ended up in this Goshala due to the indiscriminate garbage disposal by humans. Yes, these cattle end up eating plastics from mixed, unsegregated waste leading to 'Rumen impaction' and ‚Äú Non penetrating Foreign Body Syndrome‚Äù. Over a period of time, these plastic materials make large tight balls inside the rumen leading to anorexia, decreased milk production and progressive loss of body mass.

The sight of these animals with surgical scars is heart wrenching. In India all life including insects, birds and all animals have a sanctity of its own and violence against these creatures is condemned in many of our scriptures (Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism). According to the caretakers of Hingoniya, one out of 10 cattle which are brought to these rehabilitation centre dies due to the plastic waste. Rest of them barely survive the surgeries, which remove almost 50-70 kgs of plastics, nails, cables etc, from their stomachs. An estimated five million cows roam India's cities, with many gorging on the vast amounts of plastic litter on the streets. Every Indian is thus responsible for atleast one Gohathya in our lifetime.

post_desc:
Battery Waste Management Rules, 2022 notified by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Government of India yesterday (24th August 2022). New rules will replace the Batteries (Management and Handling) Rules, 2001.

The rules cover all types of batteries, viz. Electric Vehicle (EV) batteries, portable batteries, automotive batteries, and industrial batteries. This is big news as our country is gearing up for the production of EVs and none of the existing laws was covering the management of Lithium Iron battery waste.

The rules function based on the concept of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) where the producers (including importers) of batteries are responsible for the collection and recycling/refurbishment of waste batteries and the use of recovered materials from wastes into new batteries.

EPR mandates that all waste batteries to be collected and sent for recycling/refurbishment, and its prohibits disposal in landfills and incineration. To meet the EPR obligations, producers may engage themselves or authorise any other entity for collection, recycling or refurbishment of waste batteries.

On the principle of Polluter Pays Principle, environmental compensation will be imposed for non-fulfilment of Extended Producer Responsibility targets, responsibilities and obligations set out in the rules.

We have recently completed a Phase I Environmental Site Assessment (ESA) with EHS Compliance including Evaluating Electric Vehicle (EV) Battery Charging Station Specifications based on National & International Codes & Standards. Our EV Experts have worked with various leading players in the EV segment.

Name: Ashutosh Khandelwal
bio: Astrodynamics Engineer @ STAR
post_desc:
Who can be a better person to learn about the ER=EPR conjecture but it‚Äôs author itself Prof. Leonard Susskind.

Is ER=EPR Conjecture proposed by Leonard Susskind and Juan Maldacena in 2013, a solution for AMPS firewall paradox ?

ER (Einstein-Rosen) paper is on the geometry of the black holes and EPR (Einstein-Podoslky-Rosen) is a paper on quantum entanglement published in the same year 1935.

ER=EPR solves the AMPS firewall paradox by claiming that two maximally entangled black holes are connected through a warmhole.

The time evolution of the warmhole is explained using the penrose diagram of kruskal extension of schwarzschild black hole, which keeps growing till infinite space and time even after the black hole has attained its thermal equilibrium.

The authors have supported this idea by the concept of maximum complexity of a system, i.e. exponential time is taken by a quantum system to attain it‚Äôs maximum complexity, because of which warmhole is able to grow and evolve.

This conjecture also claims that any entangled particles, irrespective of their properties are connected through a planck scale warmhole.

bio: Manager at Veddis Foundation
post_desc:
A Sunday well spent attending #RACE Conclave in Lucknow on the occasion of International Plastic Bag Free Day. RACE stands for reduction, awareness, circular solutions, and mass engagement. It was organized by Deutsche Gesellschaft f√ºr Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH and UP Government.
 
With a ban on single-use plastic, there is a pressing need for entrepreneurs to come up with innovative ideas. The conclave provided budding opportunity to exhibit their innovative products such as cutlery made up of husk, bamboo pulp, bagasse, maize starch, etc. These are readily being picked up by the major restaurant chains. Some efforts to reduce plastic use is addressed by providing refill solutions to consumers as designated malls where they can get their bottle for liquid products (detergent, etc.) filled at discounted price. One startup has started delivering the same service at doorsteps by tying up with popular consumer brands. Consumer behavior change was seen as a major roadblock in its mass adoption.
 
Representatives from industries such as FMCG (Hindustan Unilever), leading cement companies and others shared about their efforts and challenges in managing plastic waste. The major challenge identified was the segregation of different categories of plastic waste for recycling. The companies shared their strategies to contribute to the circular economy of plastic, one of these shared by Hindustan Lever being adding value to plastic used in packaging such that the plastic pickers find the waste worthy for recycling. They also shared their Extended Producer Responsibility () commitments and how they are prepared to go beyond compliance to ensure net zero leakage of plastic they use for packaging to the environment.

Also, startups dealing with plastic waste segregation identified multilayer plastic packaging as a huge threat to the environment as it is difficult to viably segregate the plastic with the accessible technology.

But, as a development professional, one can always look for opportunities in the challenge posed by the plastic. Few NGOs/ institutions are actively engaged in supporting such initiatives and taking it to the masses through material recycling facilities (MRFs) in cities and villages, generating livelihoods for the poor. Such facilities require trained human resources who can benefit themselves and Mother Nature. Many other facets for livelihoods can be explored in the area. Your suggestions are welcome.

Name: Shivam Batra
bio: Building Circular Businesses and Sustainable Teams since 2013 | Believes in Shared Economy and Inclusive Growth | Lives for Social Impact!
post_desc:
Being Industry leaders and peers what is your take on EPR Policy Amendments in Plastics, E-Waste, and Batteries.

Have you read the new rules (draft) for plastics, e-waste, and batteries. Uploading draft rules on batteries that might be implemented in the near future.

My two cents on these rules are:

1. It may wipe out informal recyclers/smelters and the market would be governed by a few large players in the Industry.
2. PROs will be wiped out of the system, they may become WMAs and can act as suppliers to these large recyclers, only if they can compete on the cost(s).
3. The recyclers need to work more in strengthening their procurement channels as well as downstream vendors so as to constantly feed material in their system so as to attain ethical/clean profit(s).
4. Producers will attain easy EPR certificates from Recyclers at their desired/competitve cost(s), and each recycler will be fighting neck to neck to attract producer(s).
5. Demand for a productive and efficient workforce will increase and most of the recycler(s) will fetch talent from PROs.
6. Acquisition cost may reduce as recycler(s) will procure material directly from the source/aggregators.
7. Informal sector may get merged with the formal sector but at a slow pace of course.
8. Government may become stringent in terms of compliances and may penalize heavily if any recycler/refurbisher/producer/brand owner is found unsatisfactory.

Above is my understanding, would love to interact and learn more from each one of you. Do comment.

Whatever it unfolds, the sector is getting interesting with great opportunities for both employees as well as employers!

bio: International Consultant- Climate & Disaster Resilient Planning || Disaster and Climate Risk Data fellow || DAAD fellow || GIS Coach
post_desc:
Bring in #circulareconomy to life's every aspect! #wastetowealth
.
A recently concluded international fair in our town has left us with humongous piles of waste packaging plastic brought in by the merchants who set up their stalls in the city ground. Of course, the municipality will clean it up but taking it all to the landfill site is not a solution; it's just the attitude.
.
It is high time we introduce circular economy concepts in temporary and minor aspects of our life. If merchants/shopkeepers handle the packaging plastic carefully and take it back, it can be reused for packaging and transport. And, the municipality will not be left with taking care of huge muddy plastic piles. Also, let's not forget the environmental benefits.
.
Here is what we need:
- Cost-benefit analysis of reusing the packaging plastic by the same merchants.
- Awareness among these merchants/shopkeepers about the economic benefits of the circular economy.
- Introduction of extended producer responsibility () at the appropriate link of the supply chain
- Others (please suggest)!
